sect1.title: Features
sect1.para: Some switches can be used during configuration to enable or disable features of &app;. Some of the most important configuration options are:

listitem.para: --enable-gui lets you specify your GUI of choice. The default option is GTK.
--enable-renderer allows a renderer to be chosen. The default renderer is AGG.
--enable-media permits a media handler to be selected. The default is Gstreamer.

sect1.para: A complete list of available features follows.

row.entry: Enable support for the Flash debugger. The debugger is mainly of interest to Flash developers, and is still under development.
Enable support for the LIRC remote control protocol.
Build the Cygnal streaming media server.
Disable building all the menus for the GUI. THis is used by mobile devices without as much screen space.

Enable the generation of HTML, INFO, and MAN versions of the documentation from the Docbook XML. You will then be able to use make html, make info, and make man commands. By default, man,info and html pages are generated.

entry.para: Select the Graphic User Interface to use (choose one).

listitem.para: The GTK+ toolkit, which is the default GUI. Said to interwork particularly well with firefox.
The Hildon toolkist is based on GTK+, and is use by some mobile devices.
The ALP "Hiker" GUI is used for the Access Linux platform.
Simple DirectMedia Layer, a simple and portable GUI. Its sound facilities are used when --enable-media=ffmpeg regardless of whether it is also in charge of the GUI.
An interface adapted to the KDE Desktop Environment. This must be selected when building the Konqueror plugin "klash". Furthermore, the only renderer that currently works with KDE is opengl.
Fast Light ToolKit, low on resource usage. Since all builds using fltk are now broken, we declare it "for developers".
The Linux Frame Buffer, also known as /dev/fb0. AGG is the only renderer that can currently be used with the framebuffer GUI.

entry.para: Select the specified media decoder and sound engine. FFmpeg uses the SDL sound engine; GST uses its own. GST is the default decoder.
You should only select one media decoder.

row.entry: Force disable/enable building the NPAPI plugin. By default the Mozilla plugin is built if the GTK gui is selected. Specify the --with-npapi-plugindir= option to specify where the plugin should be installed.

Force disable/enable building the KPARTS plugin. By default the KDE plugin is built if the kde gui is selected. Specify the --with-kde-plugindir= and --with-kde-servicesdir= options (or more generally the --with-kde-pluginprefix= one) to specify where the plugin should be installed. The default installation dir is extracted from kde-config.
Disable build of both kparts and npapi plugins

Enable support for a graphics backend. Currently only opengl and agg work sufficiently. Use OpenGL when you have hardware accelerated graphics. Use AGG when you do not have hardware accelerated graphics or when you are building for a wide audience. Typically most desktop machines have OpenGL support, and most embedded systems do not. AGG is the default when building Gnash, although the speed of OpenGL's rendering is currently superior to AGG.
Enable installing the libraries and headers as an SDK.
Enable installing the shared libraries and headers. Note that the extensions mechanism may not work if shared libraries are disabled.
Turn verbose GCC compiler warnings. By default only -Wall is used with GCC.
Enable FPS debugging code. When this feature is compiled in you can use the -f switch of &app; to have FPS printed at regular intervals.
Makes the Mozilla plugin write the currently playing SWF movie to /tmp.

Drops the NPAPI plugin support for writing a standalone executable launcher script for the currently playing SWF movie to /tmp. Note that you'll still need to add a 'writelauncher' string to your GNASH_OPTIONS environment variable for the script to be created, even if the compile-time support is enabled.

Disable support for the MIT-SHM X extensions. Currently support is only available using GTK gui and AGG renderer. Keeping it enabled is not a problem as it will not be used if not available in the current X session.
